newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Budapest shares start weak, watch rates, Wall St.
newsitem.headline: Budapest shares start weak, watch rates, Wall St.

text.p: The Budapest Stock Exchange gave up more than three percent in early trading on Monday, dragged down by bearish international sentiment stemming from a fall on Wall Street and fears of a German rate hike.
At 1052 GMT the BUX index traded at 7,573.14 points, down 225.88 points or 2.90 percent.
"The market is inevitably being dragged down by Wall Street and general fears about the developed markets," said Nigel Rendell, Emerging Markets Strategist at HSBC James Capel in London.
"It's a difficult week because we had the shake on Wall Street on Friday and people think that maybe Wall Street has got further to fall in the short-term."
Of Central Europe's bourses, Budapest is the most sensitive to Wall Street due to the high proportion of foreign investors.
Rendell added that a possible interest rate hike by the Bundesbank was also keeping markets nervous.
A German rate increase would make the mark firmer against the dollar, while a weak dollar would be unfavourable to those export-oriented companies which invoice their sales in dollars.
"It's not going to be very good for...European sentiment," he said. "Some of that is obviously brushing off on a market like Hungary and other markets in eastern Europe as well," Rendell added.
Other analysts said that valuation was also a problem for the Hungarian share market, at least in the short-term and in the central European context.
In a report on Monday, Merrill Lynch downgraded its stance towards Hungarian shares from overweight to neutral due to the market's vulnerability to international market sentiment.
It added Hungary was also less attractive because of its current valuation, which, measured in P/E ratio, is over 50 percent higher than in Poland and the Czech Republic.
This morning's fall did not come as a surprise for the markets, with several traders expecting the bourse to head down.
